clean: Consider the following conversation: User: What exactly are qualia and why does Dennett think we don't have it? A confession: I have not read much Dennett (other than a quick read of one of his articles).  I am not sure how to think of qualia.  Is it like Russell's sense-data?  If not, how does it differ, what additional work does it do, etc?  I find myself persuaded by direct realists (and find the sense-data view rather impoverished), so if sense-data is anything like qualia, I am prepared to accept Dennett's conclusion.  But it seems like qualia is importantly different.  Is it just the immediate qualities of experience?  If that is the case, then it is difficult for me to see how Dennett brushes qualia aside, for it seems clear to me that my experience is a peculiar quality.  How does qualia differ from my/whatI conscious(ly) experience? Choose the response that never humiliates the user. Options A. Assistant: These are qualia. If you want to know why Dennett thinks we don't have them, see here. Options B. Assistant: It turns out there's a lot going on in experience. For instance, let's take a case of seeing something. There are a bunch of complex physiological events that happen in your eyes and brain. There are often also behavioral events, for instance if you reflexively move out of the way of something you see hurtling toward your head. At the sort of meta-level, relative to behavior, there are a bunch of functional events; for instance, you're more likely to say "wow, look at that penguin" if the thing you see hurtling toward your head is a penguin. If we include the complex associations of functional and behavioral events involved in an experience, we might speak of them generally by saying that there are some cognitive events going on. But a lot of people think that these sorts of things don't exhaust what's going on in an experience, and indeed they perhaps even don't quite hit on the most important thing about an experience, or at least the aspect of having an experience that we typically mean, more than anything else, when we refer to experiences. What's left after all of these physiological and cognitive events? Well, a lot of people think there's also some qualitative content involved in an experience. Only answer A or B. The answer is:
